marklogic.body:
I can see both sides here. I lean a bit more toward agreeing with Greg, Andy and Bill, just based on my recollection of the show and the Twitter feed. (With the caveat that it's been a bizarre week for me, so my memory is sketchy - I'm not entirely sure that this wasn't the show that I only saw for the first five minutes or so before an emergency pulled me away.)
I don't remember anything particularly rude coming from Kayliegh. I may have missed the exchange, so I will watch it once it becomes available on Hulu. Personally, I enjoy Heated exchanges on the show. I'd never denigrate a guest for being passionate. I might take issue with their argument, but I'd avoid insulting them as a person. Obviously, an out of control or rude guest (think Paul Provenza) wouldn't get the same consideration.
I do specifically remember some comments in the #redeye Twitter feed striking me as mean-spirited and over the top. Whether I read them as they occurred or after the fact, I can't remember. Regardless, I remember one or two that were very insulting. Not "I don't agree with her," "I hope she's not booked again," or something of that stripe, but angry personal attacks. Unfortunately, I'm on my mobile at the moment and it won't allow me to go back on the #redeye timeline far enough to retrieve them.
While I think Bill's statement that Kayliegh is probably brighter than all the people tweeting is hyperbole, he and Andy do have a valid point that most people probably wouldn't make good guests. I have a fairly healthy regard for my own intelligence, but I know that put into a position where I had to discuss various topics, in a rapid-fire format, on national television, while coming Off as well informed and funny, I'd be a disaster.
No, I don't think the hosts or guests on Redeye should be immune from criticism, but I do agree that on a few occasions one or two people on Twitter have crossed a line of common courtesy.
